Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Genetic diversity, resistance genes, and negative density dependence in tropical tree seedling dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests are famous for their high diversity, as well as the large number of rare species they harbor. Recent studies have found that, compared to common species, rare tropical tree species suffer more from pathogens that are specialized to a single host species that then spread rapidly through dense patches of seedlings of that single host. This research will test the novel hypothesis that rare species are more strongly impacted by host-specific pathogens because they have lower diversity of resistance genes at the population level, such that all their seedlings will be susceptible to the same suite of pathogens, promoting rapid pathogen spread and increasing mortality rates. This hypothesis will be tested using experimental greenhouse and field studies, combined with genetic analyses that will quantify the diversity of resistance genes for rare and common tree species in lowland tropical forest on Barro Colorado Island, Panama. Computer simulations will also be used to examine whether the measured differences in resistance gene diversity would impact infection levels, mortality rates and local abundance of tree species. Results of this study will improve understanding of plant-pathogen interactions, with potential applications for agriculture and horticulture (e.g. increasing pathogen resistance in crops). Hands-on training in cutting-edge genetic techniques would be provided to a wider audience through a summer workshop for students and faculty.

This study will be the first to obtain large transcriptome datasets from a tree community and will provide gene sequence data that will be informative for future studies of genetic diversity in tropical forests. Examination of the effects of resistance gene diversity on forest dynamics will bridge the gap between molecular evolution studies that indicate ongoing selection for multiple resistance genes at many loci, and how this diversity functions in nature. Furthermore, this study is likely to bridge competing theories for tropical plant diversity by providing a genetic explanation for why rare tree species are more strongly controlled by their species-specific enemies, while simultaneously supporting dispersal limitation as a feature determining which species are locally dominant. Ultimately, the study should elucidate whether local rarity restricts local genetic diversity, which in turn reinforces local rarity, a cycle that can be escaped only by recruitment of new alleles via long-distance pollen or seed movement. Demonstrating such a coupling between the ecological and genetic features of populations would bring new perspectives and avenues for theoretical advances in evolution and ecology. The project will provide research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a postdoctoral researcher.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests are famous for their high species diversity and for the large numbers of rare species they contain. Understanding how so many plant species can coexist, without one or a handful of competitively dominant species driving weaker species to extinction, has long been a challenge for ecologists. One explanation for how high numbers of plant species are maintained in tropical forests is that each species is kept in check by its host-specific natural enemies, such as fungal pathogens or insect herbivores. Such enemies can cause negative density dependence (NDD), where an individual has a lower chance of surviving when growing surrounded by neighbors of its own species rather than other species. NDD can prevent any one species from becoming dominant in the community because as a species becomes more common, its seedlings are more likely to be surrounded by high densities of their own species. This increases their chance of being attacked by their specialized herbivores and pathogens, thereby reducing seedling survival. Recent studies have revealed that tropical tree species differ in their sensitivity to neighbors of their own species, primarily due to differences in the impact of pathogens found in the soil beneath adult trees. Specifically, seedlings of some species performed poorly in soil from beneath an adult tree of their own species, while seedlings of other species were minimally impacted when growing in soil from beneath their own species.

This project tested the novel hypothesis that some species suffer stronger pathogen-caused NDD than others because they have a lower diversity of pathogen resistance (R) genes. If R gene diversity of a species is low, then seedlings of that species are more likely to be susceptible to the same suite of pathogens, which makes pathogen spread at high seedling densities more likely to occur. A critical assumption of our hypothesis is that pathogens in tropical forests are specialized not only at the level of species, but also at the level of the genotype. While genotype-specific pathogens have been well documented in agricultural and model plant systems, little is known about their existence or impact in wild plant communities.

To test our hypotheses, we worked in a highly diverse tropical forest in Panama and used a combination of experimental studies of pathogen-caused seedling mortality, genetic lab work, and computer simulations. We found that tree species that were rare in the community tended to have a lower diversity of R genes compared to locally common tree species, and that lower R gene diversity was correlated with stronger pathogen-caused NDD, consistent with our hypothesis. We also found evidence of genotype-specific pathogens in wild tropical tree species. Specifically, in a greenhouse experiment in Panama, we found that seedlings of a native tree species had reduced performance when exposed to soil collected beneath their mother tree compared to when they were exposed to soil collected from beneath other trees of their species growing in the same forest. These differences in seedling performance were unrelated to soil nutrients or to colonization by beneficial fungi, suggesting that highly specialized pathogens were the mechanism reducing seedling performance in mother soils. Using computer simulations, we also found several novel results concerning how pathogens may influence plant communities. First, our models showed that genotype-specific pathogens can help maintain plant species diversity — although less strongly than species-specific pathogens. Our models also revealed that differences among species in their sensitivity to NDD may make tree species less likely to coexist and that seed dispersal plays a large role in determining whether NDD and plant-pathogen interactions help maintain diversity in plant communities.

Our study improved understanding of what drives differences among plant species in pathogen impacts. Our findings are important for understanding how tropical plant diversity is maintained and may also offer insights into controlling pathogen impacts in forest plantations and agricultural systems. The pathogen resistance gene sequences produced by this study could also prove useful for agriculture and horticulture, specifically for defending economically important plants against soil pathogens, which would have significant economic and societal benefits. Finally, the project provided valuable training and research experience for one postdoctoral researcher and two graduate students (1 PhD and 1 Masters) at Yale University and a research technician in Panama.
